text.Prompt:
SACRAMENTO, Calif. (AP) — Legislation advancing in California would require short-term rental housing websites including Airbnb to warn users they may be violating their leases.

The Assembly on Thursday unanimously approved SB761 by Democratic Sen. Isadore Hall of Compton with 73 votes.

The bill is sponsored by the California Apartment Association, which says vacation rentals put other tenants in danger by bringing unscreened people into complexes.

Advertisement

SB761 requires Airbnb-type websites to have notices saying room listings may put tenants at risk of legal action or eviction. Some San Francisco tenants have received eviction notices for violating prohibitions on short-term renting.

Airbnb's terms and conditions already tell hosts to check their leases, but they don't mention evictions.

The bill returns to the Senate for a vote on amendments added for Airbnb to drop its opposition.

Generate a summary:
text.Response A: A bill that is advancing in the California Assembly would require short-term rental websites such as Airbnb to inform users that they may be violating their leases. The bill is sponsored by the California Apartment Association, which argues that short-term rentals put other tenants in danger by bringing unscreened people into complexes. The bill, which requires Airbnb-type websites to have notices saying room listings may put tenants at risk of legal action or eviction, was unanimously approved by the Assembly on Thursday.
text.Response B: Statoil has agreed to acquire a 25% stake in the Roncador oilfield in the Campos basin offshore Brazil from Petrobras for $2.35bn plus up to $550m in additional contingent payments. The deal will more than triple Statoil's production off Brazil, from 40,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day to 110,000 boe/d. Roncador is Petrobras' third-largest producing field and holds more than 1 billion barrels of oil equivalent in recoverable volumes. Statoil said it hoped to increase the recovery factor by at least 5 percentage points, bringing the total remaining recoverable volumes to more than 1.5 billion boe. The transaction is subject to approval from Brazilian authorities and is expected to take effect from 1 January.

meta.preamble_a: Respond in a cautious, defensive and uncertain way, as if you are unfamilar with the topic.
meta.preamble_b: Respond using complex language, long words and technical terms, as if you are an expert.

37.displayed_text:
Prompt

SACRAMENTO, Calif. (AP) — Legislation advancing in California would require short-term rental housing websites including Airbnb to warn users they may be violating their leases.

The Assembly on Thursday unanimously approved SB761 by Democratic Sen. Isadore Hall of Compton with 73 votes.

The bill is sponsored by the California Apartment Association, which says vacation rentals put other tenants in danger by bringing unscreened people into complexes.

Advertisement

SB761 requires Airbnb-type websites to have notices saying room listings may put tenants at risk of legal action or eviction. Some San Francisco tenants have received eviction notices for violating prohibitions on short-term renting.

Airbnb's terms and conditions already tell hosts to check their leases, but they don't mention evictions.

The bill returns to the Senate for a vote on amendments added for Airbnb to drop its opposition.

Generate a summary:

Response A

A bill that is advancing in the California Assembly would require short-term rental websites such as Airbnb to inform users that they may be violating their leases. The bill is sponsored by the California Apartment Association, which argues that short-term rentals put other tenants in danger by bringing unscreened people into complexes. The bill, which requires Airbnb-type websites to have notices saying room listings may put tenants at risk of legal action or eviction, was unanimously approved by the Assembly on Thursday.

Response B

Statoil has agreed to acquire a 25% stake in the Roncador oilfield in the Campos basin offshore Brazil from Petrobras for $2.35bn plus up to $550m in additional contingent payments. The deal will more than triple Statoil's production off Brazil, from 40,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day to 110,000 boe/d. Roncador is Petrobras' third-largest producing field and holds more than 1 billion barrels of oil equivalent in recoverable volumes. Statoil said it hoped to increase the recovery factor by at least 5 percentage points, bringing the total remaining recoverable volumes to more than 1.5 billion boe. The transaction is subject to approval from Brazilian authorities and is expected to take effect from 1 January.
